pull_request_title: [fix] CMake error & warning fixes on develop
comment_text:
We can just use these two lines and it'll work:

```
     find_package(catkin REQUIRED)
     catkin_package()
```

That way we don't have to find the message packages.

@cirpue49 `autoware_msgs::DetectedObject in_object;` is used in multiple tests, although its `convex_hull` member varies you can declare it `in_object` as part of  the TestSuite and initialise `header.frame_id`, `pose`, `score`, `orientation` and `dimensions` in the SetUp since they seem to be the same and clear the `convex_hull` contents in TearDown so that it is fresh for each test.
The `pose` can be overwritten in the last test where it is different.

comment_text: Thanks.
This is a bit fragile, why do you need to check `std::cout`? You could create a fixture that gets updated when a state transition or whatever the state machine does.
@esteve the tests have been updated, please have a look now. Thanks!

Looks good. I'd go further and remove `showStateName()` from the State API, so as to separate the logic from the UI (in this case the console). It's only being used in one place https://github.com/sgermanserrano/Autoware/blob/feature/test_state_machine_lib/ros/src/common/libs/state_machine_lib/src/state_context.cpp#L142

This can be rewritten as:

```TestClass() : counter_(0) {}```

Returning a const reference here should be slighty faster and it's safer to declare the method as const:

```const std::string & getStateName(void) const```
These two lines should not be deleted. I'll create a pull request https://github.com/esteve/Autoware/pull/4 that revert these lines.
Merged. Thanks!

Now that these packages have been released into the ROS index, the following will install the binary packages so we no longer need the submodule:

```
rosdep install --from-paths src --ignore-src --rosdistro $ROS_DISTRO
```

I'd rather merge this as is. There are other naming issues that need to be addressed as well (e.g. Ros vs ROS), but I think they're out of scope here. I changed `CanInfo` because there were already two other messages with a different naming convention (`CANData` and `CANPacket`).

If you refer to a value using "[key]" in std::map, there is a danger that a new element will be added if the specified key does not exist.
Therefore, you should refer to "at(key)".
```suggestion
    return transition_map_.at(key);
```

In order to clarify that there is no change in the class member variable, you should add "const" to the end of the function.
```suggestion
  uint64_t getTansitionVal(std::string key) const
```

Considering that it is a function that has been called multiple times, 
you should output "const &" without making a copy each time.
```suggestion
  const std::map<std::string, uint64_t>& getTransitionMap(void)
```

For the same reason as above, you should use "at()" for element access.
```suggestion
      _target_state_name = state_map_.at(transition_state_id)->getStateName();
```

Since it is confused with member variables, you should omit the underscore at the end of the variable.
```suggestion
  std::vector<std::string> key_list;
```
Please add a line break between functions.

@amc-nu Sorry. After I wrote the following comment, I've found that this loop can't be range-based-for because in_vision_detections->objects[i] uses index information as you mentioned above.

-----

Because I wrote it, I'd like not to delete the following comment :)

I'd like to list the merits of using range-based-for, but it's just my opinion. If you like range-based-for, please use it where range-based-for can be used in the future work :)

1. In reality, index-based-for and range-based-for generate same assembly language, i.e., same performance.
2. Range-based-for hides detail of data access.  In range-based-for, we need not manage index information, i.e., `i = 0; i < used_vision_detections.size(); i++`.
3. Range-based-for hides detail of data access. We can change the data type (e.g., from vector to list) without modifying the loops if we want.
4. The number of characters we type and review can be decreased in range-based for, especially in the case where a lot of array accesses exist.
5. The reviewer can easily understand that range-based-for just iterates each elements, and it doesn't require index information in the loop.

My choice between index-based-for and range-based-for is that

* I'll use index-based-for everywhere index information is mandatory, e.g., (1) index is used in if-statement: if(i < XXX), (2) index is used for another element: array[i + 1].
* I'll use range-based-for everywhere index information is unnecessary, i.e., each element is iterated for each iteration.

Three questions:
- What is m in roi_m_? Is it obvious if the reviewer read the paper described in README.md? Too short abbreviations often incur confusion.
- Is it a good idea to define roi_m_ and pic_scale_ to be compile-time constant (i.e., constexpr)? Because there are never changed at run-time.
- How can the reviews understand what 120 and 1800 / roi_m_ are? Are they obvious if they read the paper? If not, please explain what they are on the code. Magic number is not preferred.

Given that users may not have the CUDA and Driveworks libraries installed, this package should use the following structure:

```
find_package(CUDA)
if(CUDA_FOUND)
# The rest of the CMake code goes here
...
endif()
```

pull_request_title: Fix params and logic for responsible tracking
comment_text:
@aohsato  The only thing I am concerned is about this one. Till now we were testing with `getNearestObstaclePoint`. 
`getObstaclePoint` gets the mean of the `stop_points_`, rather than the nearest point in `stop_points` as `getNearestObstaclePoint`.

pull_request_title: Fix params and logic for responsible tracking
comment_text:
@sumanth-nirmal Your understanding is correct, but I implemented and tested `getNearestObstaclePoint` but this result is noisier than `getNearestObstaclePoint`. Several causes were considered, for example, there are some noises of ground removal.
Those noises affect KF parameters, and the responsiveness becomes worse.
is this the distance stopline to base_link?
we see really lots of missed stoplines lately. Is it possible because we check `current_velocity_ == 0.0`? Please change it to compare against epsilon.
you need to add orientation otherwise rviz crashes because the orientation is not normalized
why did you remove EObstacleType::NONE?
i somehow do not understand the meaning of this type of obstacle?
why is this extra = 4 just here in the code? and not part of distance for stopline or distance for obstacle?
right
fixed

but you have this error message, `Marker 'Stop Line/1' contains unnormalized quaternions` , so we need to focus here.
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/741beb9b1a067c7593d507b2074abf39df9d9dbf/ros/src/computing/planning/motion/packages/astar_planner/nodes/velocity_set/velocity_set.cpp#L151
you have no EObstacleType::NONE obstacle, it's just for initialization of ObstacleInfo.
exactly, I mean "obstacle on deceleration area on waypoints". but for now, we and you almost never use detection and planning for "deceleration", so I'll deprecate that.
this code block was just moved in this file and not part of them.
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/commit/a22e14eee0b769e63c79c023df0af9f18b7262be
@aohsato why is this needed?

please add a comment here why we introduced this:
Because computing lane to signal light connection is too slow in this function: https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/feature/pacmod_apex/ros/src/data/packages/vector_map_server/nodes/vector_map_server/vector_map_server.cpp#L357-L363 we go around the problem by providing a list of lights that are on our waypoint. Note: This is a semi-hack that will only work for our demo. If you record different waypoints on different lanes, you need to recreate filteredsignaldata.csv.

To make the proper fix we would need to use a different data structure instead of https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/feature/pacmod_apex/ros/src/data/packages/vector_map/include/vector_map/vector_map.h#L362 for faster querying.
